post.heading: Different Views Into The Manual
post.p: Top-down is how manuals usually are: Starts with hardware, ends with software, avoids failure. Top-down language is coherent and precise, like the Oxford dictionary. Person 1 might think top-down explanations are exquisite, clear, delightful. Person 2 might think they're stiff, boring, ignorable.

Bottom-up view gets lights flashing and motors moving ASAP. It's organized as a series of increasingly sophisticated failures. Person 1 might think it's inelegant and fragmented, but Person 2 might feel like "Yeah! The bottom-up view makes things happen!"
They both deserve a good manual. Being Person 1 in the morning, and Person 2 in the evening is perfectly normal.

Then there's also Person 3, who wants to skim, but not really follow any manual, regardless of what's in there. Person 3 will typically not read the second sentence in a paragraph like this one.
